","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Images courtesy of Takataka Plastics. ","italic":true}]}]

title: New Zealand’s capital of self-sufficiency
subtitle: What can we learn from Great Barrier Island.
author: Jasmine Balloch
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Great Barrier Island (Māori - Aotea) sits a four-hour ferry ride from Auckland and a view away from the Coromandel peninsula. The natural beauty of this island is endless; it’s a certified dark sky sanctuary and predator-free refuge for endangered birds with a heavy scattering of beaches, mountains and untouched bush. The Barrier is completely off-grid - thanks to its sheer remoteness and rough terrain. It has been noted for leading New Zealand in the use of solar power with the largest off-grid solar panel system in the country. With the majority of its homes powered by this resource, concern for the environment is right at the heart of what Great Barrier Island stands for. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"I spent the month of March on the island, staying with a couple who needed help around the house and garden. I lived in a home where water and electricity were harvested commodities and waste barely existed. Leftovers were consumed the following day, scraps fed to the chickens, cardboard boxes used for a worm farm, plastic milk bottles stuffed with non-recyclable plastics to use as bricks and glass jars repurposed to hold homemade condiments. The potential for copious amounts of household and garden waste diminished to less than a small grocery bag per week for five to six adults.  To accompany this education in rubbish reduction, my stay coincided with a 100 day stretch without rain; I quickly learnt the absurdity of letting water go down a sink. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"My hosts’ ingenuity with respect to waste is a real example to be followed – as is the island’s approach to environmental preservation in general. Look at "},{"type":"link","url":"http://protectaotea.online/","children":[{"text":"Protect Aotea"}]},{"text":":  a local organisation opposing the dumping of marine waste from Auckland harbours. The island has borne the brunt of the practice - essentially a cheap but unsustainable fix - for many years. However, residents did not take lightly to a proposed five times yearly increase in sediment dumping.  In December, protesters succeeded in winning two appeals at the High Court in Wellington, and have thus seen the plans effectively cancelled. The ruling came as a relief to local "},{"text":"iwi","italic":true},{"text":" members, concerned with preserving the Barrier for future generations."}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589626085/Screen_Shot_2020-05-16_at_11.47.00_tsoavw.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Community allows the Barrier to thrive. The acquisition of fish is just one example: fresh fish cannot be purchased on the island, so you must be a keen fisherman or know one if you want to have fresh fish for dinner. This has created a barter-type system, where home grown veg or a DIY helping hand may be exchanged for said fish. To add to this, little public transport and the price of fuel has normalised the practice of hitchhiking; the local church ‘Opp Shop’ is known as the place to go for donating unwanted items; and the food waste from the pub is donated to feed the chickens. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Island living can make everyday actions a little harder, but it foregrounds the consequences of all our actions within conscious thought. All rubbish and recycling must be transported to Auckland and supplies are delivered from there too, resulting in a collective push to be mindful of food usage and waste production. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Repurposing waste and sourcing a portion of food locally - through growing it or buying close to home – is a first step to being more self-sufficient. As we spend more time at home through this pandemic, we’re all noticing how much waste even just one household produces. Now can be the opportunity to reinvent what we do with it, taking inspiration from around the world – starting at Great Barrier Island. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589626288/Screen_Shot_2020-05-16_at_11.46.37_mm5lap.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But can something that’s effective on an island of 1000 inhabitants really be employed in heavily-populated cities? Yes, if we call for a redesign of the system to further encompass the circular economy. As we come out of the coronavirus pandemic, we will see a unique opportunity to set this in motion. A circular economy model brings with it the creation of new jobs and industry – a priority if we are to move forward from this crisis with environmental concern at the forefront."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Two main messages can be taken from the Barrier and those who call it home: "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Protect what is yours. Fight for the preservation of your home, safeguarding it for future generations. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. Living more self-sufficiently and sustainably is possible, and can work alongside a thriving economy  – if we’re willing to put the effort in. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Jasmine Balloch is about to start an Msc in Control of Infectious Diseases at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. She has worked at the University of Arizona. ","italic":true}]}]

title: One step at a time
subtitle: Ethical footwear brand Flamingos’ Life is a fashionable force for good
author: Abi Malins
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Brought up in the family business of footwear, Carlos García Sánchez always knew his own venture would revolve around social and environmental responsibility. In 2015, he founded "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/","children":[{"text":"Flamingos’ Life"}]},{"text":", an ecologically and ethically conscious footwear brand."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Organic, pesticide-free cotton, recycled plastic waste, natural corn residue and sustainably sourced rubber are handcrafted into Flamingos’ trainers, with absolutely no animal products involved. As the brand has developed, it’s also committed to tackling specific environmental and social issues with each new collection it releases."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Take the Roland design, for example. Working in collaboration with the Brussels-based NGO Waste Free Oceans, local fishermen, recycling companies and political bodies, Flamingos’ Life is aiming to reduce, reuse and recycle plastic waste that’s polluting the world’s waters. "}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“Five days before the [Spanish] state of emergency was announced we decided to work from home. It’s been really simple to adapt, with the technology available we’ve been able to keep all departments running at 100%,” says Carlos. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Each pair of Roland shoes contains roughly two recycled plastic bottles, giving polluting, wildlife-endangering plastic new life as a conscious fashion item. To date, the brand’s recycled "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/pages/rsc-oceans","children":[{"text":"over 21,000"}]},{"text":" plastic bottles. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The company’s most recent Rancho collection marks its move into using natural hemp, a material known for its low water consumption during growth, durability, and high CO2 absorption rate. “All that makes it an ideal alternative to leather or plastic, [which are] far more polluting,” Carlos tells me. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589830383/Screen_Shot_2020-05-18_at_20.32.40_bd2dxg.png","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Roland shoe. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"For each Rancho pair that’s bought, Flamingos’ plants 5 trees in collaboration with NGO Eden Reforestation Projects. The joint initiative focuses on reforesting areas of Madagascar and Mozambique to preserve precious mangrove ecosystems, revive natural habitats for rare wildlife and provide local employment opportunities. Currently, the results stand at some "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/pages/rsc-reforestation","children":[{"text":"124,800 trees planted and 3,990 working hours "}]},{"text":"generated. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carlos’ pro-environment convictions are adamant: “We’re literally killing the planet. We’ve been doing it for 50 years but the authorities concerned haven’t been aware or haven’t wanted to take sides.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"As well as promoting environmentally conscious fashion practices, Flamingos’ is holding the questionable ethics of the fashion industry to account. Fast fashion prioritises profit over fair payment and worker wellbeing, particularly as major brands outsource manufacturing to less wealthy areas of the world. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In 2018, Flamingos’ took the decision to recentralise the brand’s entire production process. Moving manufacturing from Asia back to Carlos’ local city of Elche in southeastern Spain was an important step towards ensuring total transparency within the company’s supply chain. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Producing their trainers using local, artisanal and ethically sound Spanish companies ensures there’s no exploitation within Flamingos’ production processes. By arranging local suppliers for everything from textiles to shoeboxes, they’re also reducing their carbon footprint further. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Flamingos’ recent collaboration with sustainable fashion consultancy "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bcomestudio.com/","children":[{"text":"BCOME"}]},{"text":" has confirmed fair working conditions across its entire supply chain, from growing raw materials to cutting the "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.en.flamingoslife.com/pages/rsc-manufacture","children":[{"text":"trainers’ signature ‘F’s"}]},{"text":". "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Scaling down to local production was a multi-impact decision at the time, reinforcing the brand’s climate-conscious and ethical approach. One additional, unforeseen element of that change is its direct impact on Flamingos’ ability to stay up and running during coronavirus lockdown. "}]},{"type":"image","url":"https://res.cloudinary.com/bazkingdon/image/upload/v1589830550/OCEANS-03_l4qwo9.jpg","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Working towards waste-free oceans. ","italic":true}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“Five days before the [Spanish] state of emergency was announced we decided to work from home. It’s been really simple to adapt, with the technology available we’ve been able to keep all departments running at 100%,” says Carlos. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Asked how the pandemic has affected the brand’s sustainability goals, Carlos is clear that there’s a lot the fashion sector, as well as society at large, can learn from this unprecedented situation. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“We can take positive lessons from the pandemic (with all due respect and empathy towards those who have suffered or whose relatives have fallen ill). We have to ask ourselves if the life we were leading was the right one to be healthy and happy.”"}]},{"type":"block-quote","children":[{"text":"“I think the role of the state is going to become fundamental to enabling us to save the planet in the coming years. It’s an effort all institutions have to make: state, businesses and consumers, all for one.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carlos has been following the positive environmental impact of lockdown closely, as dramatic reductions in air, sea and road travel – for both goods and people – has had a significant effect. “It’s let the planet breathe,” he says. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"But for real change to come from this crisis, there needs to be a consciously collaborative effort to change the priorities of regulating authorities, fashion companies and consumers, Carlos tells me. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“I think the role of the state is going to become fundamental to enabling us to save the planet in the coming years. It’s an effort all institutions have to make: state, businesses and consumers, all for one.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Abi Malins is a writer and translator based in Amsterdam. You can follow her on ","italic":true},{"type":"link","url":"https://twitter.com/AbiMalins","children":[{"text":"Twitter","italic":true}]},{"text":".","italic":true}]}]
